repnme.cdata!:
Gambia, The - Second Phase of the Third
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Phase of the
            Third Education Project for Gambia, The were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            this projects introduction of a performance-based
            management approach, whereby every civil servant in the
            Ministry had a performance-based contract (i.e., service
            level agreement) including teachers, administrative staff,
            both at directorate and regional levels provided important
            incentives for behavioral change at all levels. Supporting
            and drawing on local partners (private local operators) can
            be useful in ensuring effective delivery and sustainability
            of an intervention. Under the Project, literacy activities
            relied on the work of local private operators for
            implementation wherein literacy training was provided to
            more than 4,839 learners. The reach (and effectiveness) of
            this activity was likely much greater than an externally
            supported activity might have been. Improving the quality of
            teaching and teachers performance is driven by both
            capacity-building and the provision of incentives. The
            Project contributed to an increased level of confidence and
            motivation among teachers as the activities supported under
            the Project improved their content knowledge in key subjects
            and, in turn, their capacity to teach.  It is essential to
            ensure that first, teachers have the basic content knowledge
            to teach.. The teachers learning assessments undertaken by
            the project highlighted the continued need for support to
            improving teachers content knowledge. It was important to
            ensure that training covered basic knowledge needed to teach
            in lower basic schools  before covering those areas that
            would be required to receive West African Senior School
            Certificate Examination, or WASSCE credit.

repnme.cdata!:
The Gambia - Second Phase of the Third
            Education Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The framework document is designed to
            address the needs of the populations that could be affected
            by the Third Education Project by establishing policies,
            principles, institutional arrangements and indicative
            budgets. The legislation on resettlement of the government
            of the Gambia and the norms of the World Bank in its OP 4.12
            will be the instruments that will govern any resettlement
            arising out of the activities of the project. In general,
            the resettlement principles that will guide the project
            include zero displacement for the populations of any
            community and coverage by compensation of any displacement
            of persons or assets, and loss of access and services and
            attenuation of all impacts due to re-installation to an
            appropriate site. While the consultant could not at this
            stage do estimate the number of affected persons, this will
            be detailed in the resettlement action plan for each
            subproject. Several mitigating measures should be
            implemented by the project and the communities in the event
            of physical population re-location as well as the losses
            that such relocation will generate, namely: relocate the
            people affected to housing equivalent to those they left;
            reallocate land equivalent if not better than their land
            re-possessed; intensify the methods of production and
            diversify their produce or revenue generating activities
            outside their lands; and use resources created by the
            project to improve productivity. In all cases the value of
            the compensation is estimated at the current market value
            plus the added value or on the basis of the declared value
            to the fiscal authorities. For those who may lose
            employment: create cottage industries and revenue generating
            activities; and encourage husbandry of small ruminants; and
            fish farming from hand-dug ponds, etc. The displaced persons
            must not suffer any prejudice with regard to access to
            natural resources and services. Overall, the displaced
            persons whether individuals, families or communities with
            certain affinities must be assisted by the project and the
            communities to reconstruct their livelihoods without any
            form of alienation, in particular by the host communities.
            The right of use of the land and the forest code are
            recognised and presents no conflicts as far as project
            implementation but the mining code may, pose problems in
            certain rural communities, such as in the Khosanto and
            Missirah Sirimana in Tambacounda region where the sub-soil
            contains gold deposits. The risks of resettlement to the
            population and project locations will be there when
            industrial exploitation of the deposits is decided. The
            report recommends prior sensitization of the community and
            establishing mechanisms for settling disputes.

repnme.cdata!:
The Gambia - Second Phase of the Third
            Education Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental and social
            management framework for the Third Education (Phase 2)
            Project for the Gambia, which builds and repairs water and
            sanitation facilities and infrastructure and access roads
            while focusing on improving educational quality and access.
            Adverse environmental impacts of the project would mainly
            come from construction activities related to the project
            infrastructure and related services prior to, during and
            after the construction activities and notably the lack of or
            inadequacy of water and sanitation facilities as well as
            fencing. These should be addressed by ensuring that any
            mitigation measures are incorporated into the contracts. A
            major rehabilitation program of educational infrastructure
            should be undertaken. Other potential adverse environmental
            impacts include degradation of storage sites; loss of
            vegetation and degradation of soils, surface water
            pollution; deforestation for construction site access and
            quarry use; air pollution due to vehicle rotation, noise,
            soil pollution from motor oil and lubricants; waste
            generated by construction work; soil erosion; loss of
            natural habitat zones and biodiversity; unserviceable
            sanitation facilities and absence of access to water and
            electricity; unrehabilitated quarries and borrow pits
            (habitats for the malaria vector and bilharzia snail);
            non-restoration of the landscape and regeneration of the
            vegetation cover; risks of bush fires by uncontrolled
            burning; river sedimentation; clogged drainage; pollution
            and temporary disruption of river out-flow (by materials
            storage); accidental discharge of oils, of greases; traffic
            accidents risks; and traffic disruption; emanation of dust ;
            increased water use and competition for the use of natural
            resources;  increased levels of soil salinity; proliferation
            of invading aquatic plants, development of water related
            diseases (malaria, bilharzias, etc.); reduced arable and
            pastoral surfaces; pesticides poisoning; and disappearance
            of grazing lands, among others. Possible mitigation measures
            will include: collecting and storing worksite refuse; safety
            measures; an HIV/AIDS awareness campaign; traffic diversion
            plans; respect hygiene and security on worksite; traffic
            signals; ensure compliance with safety rules; involve local
            communities; reclaim quarries; avoid excavation in protected
            areas; distance site and latrines from waterways; provide
            effluent treatment of liquid waste before discharging ;
            support affordable pump out services; assign routine
            cleaning and maintenance services; promote latrine use;
            collect and store manure; consider using bio-gas; provide
            protective clothing; avoid pesticide overuse and choose
            agro-chemicals; limit animal numbers; control animal
            grazing; reseed and produce fodder; range management; liquid
            and solid waste disposal or treatment; manage animal
            processing facilities; control noise; and monitor pollutant
            concentration in air;. Other measures were suggested for
            controlling impacts to human health, soils, the social
            environment, water quality, and animals and wildlife.

The Gambia - Second Phase of the
            Third Education Project : environmental assessment (Vol. 2)
            : Environmental and social management framework

repnme.cdata!:
Gambia, The - Additional Financing for the
            Second Phase of Third Education Sector Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective Additional Financing for
            the Second Phase of Third Education Sector Project is to
            improve access of underserved communities to, and quality,
            of education in The Gambia, with a particular focus on
            primary education (lower-basic education) and teacher
            quality. The restructuring seeks the approval of the
            Regional Vice President (RVP) to extend the closing dates of
            the original financing and of the additional financing to
            December 31, 2013, in order to: 1) allow completion of
            certain Project activities, 2) reallocate proceeds between
            disbursement categories, 3) expand the scope of financing of
            H590 to component three of the project in order to finance
            civil works that were initially to be financed from H230,
            and 4) adjust the results framework to amend some targets as
            commensurate with sectoral progress and to be better aligned
            with the slightly adjusted project activities.

display_title.display_title:
Gambia, The - Additional
            Financing for the Second Phase of Third Education Sector
            Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Gambia, The - Additional Financing for the
            Second Phase of Third Education Sector Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective Additional Financing for
            the Second Phase of Third Education Sector Project is to
            improve access of underserved communities to, and quality,
            of education in The Gambia, with a particular focus on
            primary education (lower-basic education) and teacher
            quality. The restructuring seeks the approval of the
            Regional Vice President (RVP) to extend the closing dates of
            the original financing and of the additional financing to
            December 31, 2013, in order to: 1) allow completion of
            certain Project activities, 2) reallocate proceeds between
            disbursement categories, 3) expand the scope of financing of
            H590 to component three of the project in order to finance
            civil works that were initially to be financed from H230,
            and 4) adjust the results framework to amend some targets as
            commensurate with sectoral progress and to be better aligned
            with the slightly adjusted project activities.
